title: Data pertaining to the apology issued by Sheffield Tree Action Group publicly acknowledged by Sir Mark Lowcock

content:
Dear Sheffield City Council,
Please provide any and all data associated with the apology issued by Sheffield Tree Action Group on behalf of 'campaigners', which was referenced by Sir Mark Lowcock when speaking in public at the Council meeting on 10th May 2023.
Including any related internal dialogues between members and / or officers.
Many thanks and kind regards
Mr. Buxton

Dear Mr. Buxton,
Thank you for your request for information relating to STAG apology which
we received on 26/02/2025.
This has been logged as a Freedom of Information Request and will be dealt
with under the Freedom of Information Act 2000. The reference number for
your request can be found above.
The Freedom of Information Act 2000 states that we must respond to you
within 20 working days, by 27/03/2025. Please do not hesitate to contact
us at the email address below if you have any queries.
Please note that from 1^st January 2025, as part of our commitment to
improving services, the council will accept FOI requests via the online

[1]Freedom of Information and Environmental Information requests |
Sheffield City Council
Please bookmark this link for future requests.
The online form is linked directly to our systems in the FOI service as
part of our continued improvement to streamline processes.
Yours sincerely,

Dear Mr Buxton,
Thank you for your Freedom of Information Request Reference 1769966 which
we received on 26/2/2025 and for which we sought clarification on
18/3/2025. You responded to us on 4/4/2025 and we have calculated our
response date from 7/4/2025, which was the next working day. Therefore,
our response is due on or before 7/5/2025.
You have asked us for: ‘all data associated with the apology made by
Sheffield Tree Action Group on behalf of campaigners, as refer to by Sir
Mark Lowcock in his address to the Sheffield City Council Extraordinary
General Meeting on 10th May 2023’.
Since you have not indicated any specific information you require, in
order to answer your request we sought permission from the Data Protection
Officer to undertake an e-Discovery search of email systems. This had
resulted in 428 items identified for the period 6/3/2023 (publication of
the Lowcock report) – 10/5/2023 (the reference to the apology in the
meeting). There were a further 1,196 items for the period
11/5/2023-11/8/2023. We felt this to be the most likely period in which
the apology made by the Sheffield Tree Action Group (STAG) would be
discussed. Our search used the terms ‘STAG’ and ‘apology’.
Whilst many of these are likely to be repetitious or not relevant: i.e.
email threads with multiple recipients or not about the STAG apology (for
example the sentence ‘I have received your meeting apology’ would be
caught in our search if the message also mentioned ‘STAG’) and the
council’s own apology;  we would need to assess each item to determine its
relevance to your request and then extract the appropriate item into a
redactable format. Under Regulation 4(3) of the Fees Regulations we can
include these activities when calculating the cost of compliance. We
estimate that each item would take an average of five minutes to assess
and extract: for the first period the 428 items would take 35 hours to
process and the second, up to 100 hours. This calculation does not include
the time taken to apply redactions. The Information Commissioner’s
guidance on this is explained here: [1]Requests where the cost of
compliance exceeds the appropriate limit (section 12) | ICO
The information you have requested in your request (FOI 1769966) is exempt
from disclosure under section 12 of the Freedom of Information Act 2000 on
the grounds that cost of compliance would exceed the appropriate limit.
The cost limit (18 hours or £450) is specified in the [2]Freedom of
Information and Data Protection (Appropriate Limit and Fees) Regulations
2004 (SI 2004 No. 3244).
Under section 16 of the Freedom of Information Act 2000, we have a duty to
provide advice and assistance to requesters. If you would like to narrow
down the focus of your request, we would be happy to process your revised
request as a new request for information under the Freedom of Information
Act 2000. If there is specific information you are looking for or
discussions between certain individuals, we are happy to conduct further
searches to see if we can answer your request. From our previous
correspondence and information available in the public domain, we believe
you have knowledge of the individuals in the council who may be of
interest, but we may be able to provide additional assistance should you
require it.
The information provided in this response is available for re-use under
the terms of the Open Government Licence v3.0. The terms of the OGL can be
found [3]here. When re-using the information, Sheffield City Council
requires you to include the following attribution statement: “Contains
public sector information obtained from Sheffield City Council and
licensed under the Open Government Licence v3.0.”
If you are unhappy with the response you have received in relation to your
request, you are entitled to have this reviewed. You can ask for an
internal review by replying to this email. Internal review requests should
be submitted within 40 working days from the date of this response.
If you remain dissatisfied with the outcome of your internal review, you
can contact the Information Commissioner’s Office. Please see
[4]
https://ico.org.uk/make-a-complaint/offi...
for further details.
Kind Regards,
FOI Team
Sheffield City Council
PO Box 1283
Sheffield, S1 1UJ
